How many are conditions?
For what purpose is the investigation of conditions?
It means that because of cause, because of immediate succession, because of object, and because of predominance, there is the meaning of condition.
All are conditions.
In order to abandon attachment to the self as the cause of dharmas, one investigates conditions.
What are the causal conditions?
It means the store consciousness and wholesome habitual tendencies.
Moreover, the meaning of causal conditions is in terms of intrinsic nature, distinctions, assisting companions, equal practice, enhancement, obstruction, and inclusion.
The intrinsic nature means the efficient cause.
The distinctions in intrinsic nature refer to the distinctions in the efficient cause, which are briefly of twenty kinds.
1. The efficient cause of production, which refers to the combination of consciousnesses with regard to consciousness.
2. The efficient cause of abiding, which refers to food with regard to sentient beings who have been born and those seeking birth.
The third is the ability to hold, which refers to the great earth in relation to sentient beings.
The fourth is the ability to illuminate, which refers to lamps and so forth in relation to forms.
The fifth is the ability to transform and destroy, which refers to fire in relation to firewood.
The sixth is the ability to separate, which refers to sickles and so forth in relation to what is to be cut.
The seventh is the ability to transform, which refers to the wisdom of skilled crafts in relation to things such as gold and silver.
The eighth is the ability to believe and understand, which refers to smoke in relation to fire.
The ninth is the ability to make clear, which refers to the thesis, reason, and example in relation to the meaning to be established.
The tenth is the ability to attain, which refers to the noble path in relation to nirvÄá¹‡a.
The eleventh is the ability to explain, which refers to names, thoughts, and views.
The twelfth is the ability to depend, which refers to the arising of desire for something due to dependence on it, such as seeking food and drink in dependence on hunger and thirst.
The thirteenth is the ability to lead, which refers to distant conditions, such as ignorance in relation to old age and death.
The fourteenth is the ability to give rise, which refers to proximate conditions, such as ignorance in relation to karmic formations.
The fifteenth is assisting productive power, which is the remaining conditions, such as the field, water, and fertilizer, etc., in regard to the production of grain, etc.
The sixteenth is attracting productive power, which is the condition of conformity, such as properly serving the king in order to please him.
The seventeenth is determining productive power, which is the condition of discrimination, such as the five destinies in regard to the fruit of the five destinies.

The eighteenth is cooperating productive power, which is the condition of union, such as the unimpaired faculties, the presence of an object, and the correct arising of attention in regard to the consciousness that is produced.
The nineteenth is opposing productive power, which is the condition of obstruction, such as hail in regard to grain.
The twentieth is nonopposing productive power, which is the condition of nonobstruction, such as grain without obstruction.
An associate is those dharmas that are born together and necessarily are not lacking, such as the four great elements and the derivative form, according to what is appropriate.
Equal activity is those dharmas that are born together and equally active in regard to the object and are necessarily not lacking, such as mind and its activities.
Augmentation means that by cultivating good, bad, and indeterminate dharmas in the past, one can cause good, etc., dharmas in the future to gradually increase and be born one after another.

Obstruction means that according to the number of afflictions one cultivates, all the afflictions one has can continue, increase, and become firm, causing one's continuity to stay far away from nirvÄá¹‡a.
Subsumption means that unwholesome and wholesome contaminated dharmas can subsume their own essence.
What is the similar and immediately antecedent condition?
It means that there is no interval in the middle, because they are similar and immediately antecedent.
The mind and mental factors of the same type and different types are born because they are similar and immediately antecedent.
This is the meaning of the similar and immediately antecedent condition.
What is the object condition?

That is, because it is the object of a limited realm, because it is the object of an unlimited realm, because it is the object of a non-differentiated aspect, because it is the object of a differentiated aspect, because it is the object of an existent thing, because it is the object of a non-existent thing, because it is the object of an existent thing, because it is the object of discrimination, because it is the object of error, because it is the object of non-error, because it is the object of obstruction, and because it is the object of non-obstruction, this is the meaning of the condition of object.
What is the dominant condition?

That is, because of the dominant condition of support, because of the dominant condition of attraction, because of the dominant condition of co-existence, because of the dominant condition of object, because of the dominant condition of production, because of the dominant condition of maintenance, because of the dominant condition of experiencing the result, because of the dominant condition of worldly purification and detachment, and because of the dominant condition of supramundane purification and detachment, this is the meaning of the dominant condition.ğŸ”½What is similar and dissimilar?
How many are similar and dissimilar?
For what purpose does one contemplate homogeneity and its opposite?

That is to say, because the similar faculties that are not separate from consciousness arise in continuity with regard to objects, and because the similar self that is separate from consciousness arises in continuity, this is the meaning of homogeneity and its opposite.
One part of the form aggregate, the five beginning with the eye, and one part of the sense bases of the form realm are homogeneity and its opposite.
In order to abandon attachment to a self that is associated with or not associated with consciousness, one contemplates homogeneity and its opposite.ğŸ”½What is appropriation?
How many are appropriation?
For what purpose does one contemplate appropriation?
That is to say, because form is the basis for the arising of feeling, this is the meaning of appropriation.
One part of the form aggregate, the five entire sense bases of the form realm, and four parts are appropriation.
In order to abandon attachment to a self that freely turns the body, one contemplates appropriation.ğŸ”½What is a faculty?
How many are faculties?
For what purpose does one contemplate faculties?

That is, because of the supremacy of grasping objects, the supremacy of the continuity of the family, the supremacy of abiding in the same destiny, the supremacy of experiencing the fruits of pure and impure karma, the supremacy of worldly detachment, and the supremacy of supramundane detachment, these are the meanings of faculties.

The entire aggregate of feeling and the aggregate of consciousness, part of the aggregate of form and the aggregate of volitional formations, the entire twelve sense bases and six sense spheres, and part of the sense base and sense sphere of mental objects are faculties. In order to abandon attachment to a dominant self, one contemplates faculties.
What is the nature of suffering as suffering?
How many are the nature of suffering as suffering?
For what purpose does one contemplate the nature of suffering as suffering?

That is, because of the intrinsic nature of painful feeling itself and because of the intrinsic nature of dharmas that accord with painful feeling, these are the meanings of the nature of suffering as suffering.
All are partially the nature of suffering as suffering.
In order to abandon attachment to a self that has suffering, one contemplates the nature of suffering as suffering.ğŸ”½What is the nature of suffering as change?
How many are the nature of suffering as change?
For what purpose does one contemplate the nature of suffering as change?

That is to say, because the characteristics of pleasant feeling are subject to change, because the characteristics of the dharmas that accompany pleasant feeling are subject to change, and because the mind that is attached to them is subject to change. This is the meaning of the nature of the suffering of change.
All of them are, to a certain extent, the nature of the suffering of change.
One contemplates the nature of the suffering of change in order to eliminate grasping a self that is happy.
What is the nature of the suffering of the karmic process?
How many are the nature of the suffering of the karmic process?
For what purpose does one contemplate the nature of the suffering of the karmic process?

That is to say, because the characteristics of neither pleasant nor unpleasant feeling are subject to the karmic process, because the characteristics of the dharmas that accompany neither pleasant nor unpleasant feeling are subject to the karmic process, because they are included in the coarseness of the two , and because they are not free from the anxiety of the impermanence of the two . This is the meaning of the nature of the suffering of the karmic process.
Except for the aggregates that are part of the three realms and two sense bases, all of them are the nature of the suffering of the karmic process.
One contemplates the nature of the suffering of the karmic process in order to eliminate grasping a self that is neither happy nor unhappy.ğŸ”½What has retribution?ğŸ”½How many have retribution?
For what purpose does one contemplate that which has retribution?
That is, the unwholesome and the wholesome contaminated are with retribution.
One part of the aggregates, elements, and sense bases that are not good, etc., are with retribution.
In order to abandon attachment to a self that is able to abandon and continue the aggregates, one contemplates that which is with retribution.
Moreover, that which has retribution refers only to the store consciousness and its associated mental activities. The rest are born of retribution but are not retribution.
What is nutriment?
How many are nutriment?
For what purpose is nutriment investigated?

That which is nutriment is in the sense of transformation, that which has transformation is in the sense of object, that which has an object is in the sense of desire, and that which desires is in the sense of grasping. That which has grasping is the meaning of nutriment.
One part of the three aggregates, eleven elements, and five sense bases is nutriment.
In order to abandon attachment to a self that abides by means of nutriment, one investigates nutriment.
Moreover, the establishment of the various kinds of nutriment is briefly fourfold:

The first is the food of abiding in dependence on the impure, the second is the food of abiding in dependence on the pure and impure, the third is the food of abiding in dependence on the pure, and the fourth is the food of manifesting abiding.ğŸ”½What is superior?
How many are superior?
For what purpose does one contemplate the superior?
It means that because of all conditioned phenomena and a part of unconditioned phenomena, there is the meaning of the superior.
Except for a part of the dharma realm and dharma realm objects, all are superior.
In order to abandon attachment to the self of inferior things, one contemplates the superior.
What is non-superior?
How many are non-superior?
For what purpose does one contemplate the non-superior?
It means that because of a part of the unconditioned, there is the meaning of the non-superior.
A part of the dharma realm and dharma realm objects is non-superior.
In order to abandon attachment to the self of the most excellent things, one contemplates the non-superior.
By means of the principle of distinction that has been explained, one can contemplate the innumerable other aspects in the same way.

Furthermore, the distinctions of aggregates, realms, and sense bases are generally of three kinds: distinctions of imagined characteristics, distinctions of discriminated characteristics, and distinctions of the characteristics of the nature of dharmas.
What are the distinctions of imagined characteristics?
It refers to the imagined self, sentient being, life, birth, nourishment, appropriator, mind-born, and so forth, in the aggregates, realms, and sense bases.
What are the distinctions of discriminated characteristics?
It refers to the dharmas of the aggregates, realms, and sense bases themselves.
What are the distinctions of the characteristics of the nature of dharmas?
It refers to the absence of self-nature in the self, etc., and the presence of self-nature in non-self, in the aggregates, realms, and sense bases.
There are also four kinds of distinctions, namely distinctions of characteristics, distinctions of discrimination, distinctions of basis, and distinctions of continuity.
What are the distinctions of characteristics?
It refers to the distinctions of the individual characteristics of the aggregates, realms, and sense bases.
What are the distinctions of discrimination?

That is to say, in the aggregates, elements, and sense bases, there is real existence, nominal existence, conventional existence, ultimate existence, form, and the formless, the visible and the invisible, and so on, with innumerable distinctions. The distinctions are as explained above.
What is the distinction of basis?
It is that there are as many distinctions in the aggregates, elements, and sense bases as there are distinctions in the basis of sentient beings.
What is the distinction of continuity?
It is the transformation of the aggregates, elements, and sense bases in each moment.
What is the knowledge of skill in the distinction of characteristics?
It is the knowledge of the faults of the view of self.
What is the knowledge of skill in the distinction of discrimination?
It is the knowledge of the faults of the view of aggregation.
What is the knowledge of skill in the distinction of basis?
It is the knowledge of the faults of the view that one can obtain without action and lose through action.
What is the knowledge of skill in the distinction of continuity?
It is the knowledge of the faults of the view of abiding.

Furthermore, the aggregates, realms, and sense bases have six kinds of distinctions, namely, distinctions of the external gate, distinctions of the internal gate, distinctions of long duration, distinctions of limited duration, distinctions of temporary duration, and distinctions of manifestation.
What are the distinctions of the external gate?
It refers to the distinctions of the desire realm for the most part.
What are the distinctions of the internal gate?
It refers to all stages of concentration.
What are the distinctions of long duration?
It refers to all ordinary beings.
What are the distinctions of limited duration?
It refers to all learners, and all post-learners except for the final moment of the aggregates, realms, and sense bases.
What are the distinctions of temporary duration?
It refers to the final moment of the aggregates, realms, and sense bases of all post-learners.
What are the distinctions of manifestation?
It refers to the aggregates, realms, and sense bases manifested by the Buddhas and bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who have attained the ultimate.
Chapter on Compendium, Section on Fundamental Topics, Compendium Chapter 2: What is included?

In brief, there are eleven kinds of inclusion: inclusion of characteristics, inclusion of realms, inclusion of kinds, inclusion of states, inclusion of companions, inclusion of directions, inclusion of time, partial inclusion, complete inclusion, mutual inclusion, and ultimate inclusion.
What is inclusion of characteristics?
It means that each of the aggregates, realms, and sense bases includes itself by its own characteristics.
What is inclusion of realms?
It means that the seeds of the aggregates, realms, and sense bases in the store consciousness can include those realms.
What is inclusion of kinds?

It means that although the characteristics of the aggregates, realms, and sense bases differ, they mutually include each other because they are the same in meaning as aggregates, realms, and sense bases.
What is inclusion of states?
It means that the aggregates, realms, and sense bases in a pleasant state are included by their own characteristics.
The same is true for the unpleasant and neutral states, because the states are the same.
What is inclusion of companions?
It means that the form aggregate includes the other aggregates because they are companions to each other. The same is true for the other aggregates, realms, and sense bases.
What is inclusion of directions?
That is to say, the aggregates, elements, and sense bases in the east are included in their own characteristics, and so are the aggregates, elements, and sense bases in the other directions.
What is inclusion in terms of time?
That is to say, the aggregates, elements, and sense bases in the past are included in their own characteristics, and so are the aggregates, elements, and sense bases in the future and present.
What is inclusion in terms of part?
That is to say, all dharmas that are included in the aggregates, elements, and sense bases only include a part and not the rest, and one should know that this is inclusion in terms of part.
What is inclusion in terms of whole?
That is to say, all dharmas that are included in the aggregates, elements, and sense bases are able to include the whole part, and one should know that this is inclusion in terms of whole.
What is mutual inclusion?
That is to say, how many elements and sense bases are included in the form aggregate?
Ten wholes and one part.
How many elements and sense bases are included in the feeling aggregate?
One part.
As with the feeling aggregate, so it is with the perception and formation aggregates.
How many elements and sense bases are included in the consciousness aggregate?
Seven elements and one sense base.
How many aggregates and sense bases are included in the eye element?
One part of the form aggregate and one whole sense base.
The ear, nose, tongue, body, form, sound, smell, taste, and touch elements are also like this.
How many aggregates and how many sense bases are included in the mind element?
One aggregate and one sense base.
How many aggregates and how many sense bases are included in the dharma element?
Three aggregates in their entirety, a part of the form aggregate, and one sense base in its entirety.
How many aggregates and how many sense bases are included in the eye consciousness element?
The consciousness aggregate and a part of the mind sense base.
The ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness elements are also like this.
How many aggregates and how many elements are included in the eye sense base?
A part of the form aggregate and one element in its entirety.
The ear, nose, tongue, body, form, sound, smell, taste, and touch sense bases are also like this.
How many aggregates and how many elements are included in the mind sense base?
One aggregate and seven elements.
How many aggregates and how many elements are included in the dharma sense base?
Three aggregates in their entirety, a part of one aggregate, and one element in its entirety.

In this way, the other dharmas are explained by the names of aggregates, elements, and sense bases, as well as by the names of those that are not aggregates, elements, and sense bases. They are truly existent, conventionally existent, and ultimately existent. They are knowable, cognizable, and penetrable. They are form and formless, visible and invisible. In this way, they are as previously explained. As appropriate, they are all to be understood as mutually included within the aggregates, elements, and sense bases.
What is ultimate inclusion?
It refers to the aggregates, elements, and sense bases being included within suchness.
What benefits are obtained through skill in inclusion?
One obtains the benefit of being able to briefly gather the objects of cognition.
One briefly gathers the mind towards those various objects, and in this way the wholesome roots become increasingly superior.
Chapter 3: Correspondence, from the Section on the Fundamental Doctrines of the Compendium of the Great Vehicle Abhidharma What is correspondence?

In brief, there are six kinds of association: non-separation association, combination association, aggregation association, co-existence association, doing the same thing association, and doing the same activity association.
What is non-separation association?
It refers to all material forms with spatial dimensions being mutually non-separated in their locations with the most subtle particles.
What is combination association?
It refers to all material forms with spatial dimensions above the most subtle particles combining with each other.
What is aggregation association?
It refers to the mutual gathering of material forms with spatial dimensions and aggregation.
What is co-existence association?
It refers to the aggregates, realms, and sense bases in a single body co-existing, simultaneously arising, abiding, and ceasing.
What is doing the same thing association?
It refers to mutually embracing in doing a single thing, like two monks doing a single thing and mutually corresponding.
What is doing the same activity association?
It refers to the mind and mental factors doing the same activity on a single object.

This corresponding association of the same type has many meanings, namely, corresponding association of other natures, not one's own nature; corresponding association of non-opposition, not opposition; corresponding association of the same time, not different times; corresponding association of the same realm and stage, not different realms and stages.
There is also corresponding association of the same type that is universal,
namely, feeling, conceptualization, volition, contact, and mental consciousness.
There is also corresponding association of the same type that is defiled and universal, namely, the four kinds of afflictions in the defiled mind.

There is also corresponding association of the same type that is not always present, namely, the mind that sometimes gives rise to wholesome dharmas such as faith, or sometimes gives rise to afflictions and secondary afflictions such as craving.

There is also corresponding association of the same type that is based on states, namely, dharmas that correspond with pleasant feeling, and dharmas that correspond with painful feeling and neither painful nor pleasant feeling.ğŸ”½There is also corresponding association of the same type that is uninterrupted, namely, in the state of having mind.
There is also corresponding association of the same type that is interrupted, namely, interrupted by the concentration without mind.
There is also association of the same activity through the external sense consciousnesses, namely, the majority of minds and mental activities of the realm of desire.
There is also association of the same activity through the internal sense consciousnesses, namely, minds and mental activities in the various samÄdhis.
There is also association of the same activity through minds and mental activities that have been cultivated, namely, those of ordinary persons and a part of those of the two vehicles.

There is also association of the same activity through minds and mental activities that have not been cultivated, namely, supramundane minds and mental activities, and those that are obtained subsequently.
What benefit is there in being skilled in association?
One can understand thoroughly the meaning of association and nonassociation of such dharmas as feeling, conceptualization, etc., that are supported by mind.

By understanding this, one can abandon the attachment to the defilement and purity of the self that feels, conceptualizes, thinks, and remembers, and one can skillfully and quickly enter into nonself.
Chapter 4: Accomplishment, in the section on the main points of the Compendium of the Great Vehicle Abhidharma, the fourth chapter on accomplishment. What is accomplishment?
The characteristics of accomplishment are as explained above.
There are three kinds of distinctions, namely accomplishment of seeds, accomplishment of mastery, and accomplishment of actual dharmas.
What is accomplishment of seeds?
If one is born in the desire realm, afflictions and secondary afflictions belonging to the desire, form, and formless realms are accomplished by virtue of the accomplishment of seeds;
and innate wholesome [dharmas].
If one is born in the form realm, afflictions and secondary afflictions belonging to the desire realm are accomplished by virtue of the accomplishment of seeds;
they are also called non-accomplished. Afflictions and secondary afflictions belonging to the form and formless realms are accomplished by virtue of the accomplishment of seeds;
and innate wholesome [dharmas].
If one is born in the formless realm, afflictions and secondary afflictions belonging to the desire and form realms are accomplished by virtue of the accomplishment of seeds.
It is also called non-accomplishment. The afflictions and secondary afflictions bound to the formless realm are accomplished by the accomplishment of seeds.
And the innate wholesome [dharmas].

If one has already attained the path that counteracts the three realms, as such and such types of counteraction arise, such and such types [of afflictions] are not accomplished due to the non-accomplishment of seeds.
As such and such types of counteraction have not yet arisen, such and such types [of afflictions] are accomplished due to the accomplishment of seeds.
What is accomplishment by mastery?
It refers to the wholesome dharmas of added effort.

The wholesome dharmas of the mundane and supramundane concentrations, liberations, samÄdhis, samÄpattis, etc., as well as a part of the indeterminate dharmas, are accomplished due to the accomplishment by mastery.
What is accomplishment by manifestation?
It refers to the aggregates, sense bases, and elements. The dharmas that manifest, whether wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate, are accomplished due to the accomplishment by manifestation.
If one has already severed wholesome [roots], all wholesome dharmas are accomplished by the accomplishment of seeds.
They are also called non-accomplished. If one is not a person of nirvana, one ultimately accomplishes all defiled dharmas.
Due to the lack of causes for liberation, one is also called an icchantika, because the causes for attaining liberation are ultimately not accomplished.
What benefits are gained by being skilled in accomplishment?
One can thoroughly understand the increase and decrease of dharmas.
Knowing increase and decrease, one is free from the notion of permanence regarding the rise and fall of the world, and can even sever attachment and aversion.

Up to one day and one month, the light shines everywhere, and the place illuminated is called one world. In this way, in the thousand worlds there are a thousand suns, a thousand moons, a thousand Sumeru kings, a thousand great continents, a thousand Four Heavenly Kings, a thousand Thirty-three Heavens, a thousand YÄma Heavens, a thousand Tuá¹£ita Heavens, a thousand NirmÄá¹‡arati Heavens, a thousand ParanirmitavaÅ›avartin Heavens, and a thousand Brahma Heavens. In this way, the great trichiliocosm is completely surrounded by the great outer ring of mountains.
Moreover, this great trichiliocosm is destroyed and formed together.

It is like rain falling from the sky in drops as large as chariot axles, without interval or interruption, and in the same way, in the east, without interval or interruption, there are innumerable worlds, some about to be destroyed, some about to be formed, some being destroyed, some already destroyed and remaining so, some being formed, and some already formed and remaining so.
As in the east, so also in all the ten directions.

Whether it be the world of sentient beings or the physical world, because they are produced by the power of karma and afflictions, and because they are brought about by the dominant influence of karma and afflictions, they are collectively called the truth of suffering.

There are also pure worlds that are not included in the truth of suffering, because they are not produced by the power of karma and afflictions, and because they are not brought about by the dominant influence of karma and afflictions, but are rather attracted by the dominant influence of great vows and pure wholesome roots.
The place where they are born is inconceivable, and only Buddhas can understand it;
it is not even the realm of those who have attained meditative concentration, let alone those who engage in discursive thought.

Furthermore, the characteristics of suffering are distinguished as eight kinds: the suffering of birth, the suffering of old age, the suffering of sickness, the suffering of death, the suffering of being with what is disliked, the suffering of separation from what is loved, the suffering of not obtaining what one seeks, and in brief, the suffering of the five appropriated aggregates.
Why is birth suffering?
Because it is oppressed by many sufferings and because it is the basis for other sufferings.
Why is old age suffering?
Because it is the suffering of the change of time.
Why is sickness suffering?
Because it is the suffering of the change of the great elements.
Why is death suffering?
Because it is the suffering of the change of life.
Why is being with what is disliked suffering?
Because it produces the suffering of being together.
Why is separation from what is loved suffering?
Because it produces the suffering of separation.
Why is not obtaining what one seeks suffering?
Because it produces the suffering of not obtaining what one desires.
Why are the five appropriated aggregates in brief suffering?
Because they are the suffering of being oppressed.

These eight are summarized as six: the suffering of oppression, the suffering of transformation, the suffering of union, the suffering of separation, the suffering of not getting what one desires, and the suffering of coarseness.
These six are expanded to eight, and whether six or eight, they are equal in equality.
As the three kinds of suffering are explained, are the eight kinds of suffering included in the three, or are the three included in the eight?
They mutually include each other.
The suffering of birth, old age, sickness, death, and union with the disliked manifests the suffering of suffering;
The suffering of separation from the loved and not getting what one desires manifests the suffering of change;
The suffering of the five appropriated aggregates in brief manifests the suffering of formations.
As the two kinds of suffering are explained, namely the suffering of conventional truth and the suffering of ultimate truth.
What is the suffering of conventional truth?
What is the suffering of ultimate truth?
The suffering of birth up to the suffering of not getting what one desires is the suffering of conventional truth.
In brief, it includes all the suffering of the five aggregates that are grasped, which is the suffering of the ultimate truth.
What is the common characteristic of the truth of suffering?
It refers to the characteristics of impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self.
What is the characteristic of impermanence?

In brief, there are twelve, namely the characteristic of non-existence, the characteristic of destruction, the characteristic of change, the characteristic of separation, the characteristic of manifestation, the characteristic of natural law, the characteristic of a moment, the characteristic of continuity, the characteristic of illness, etc., the characteristic of the transformation of various mental activities, the characteristic of the rise and fall of wealth, and the characteristic of the formation and destruction of the world.
What is the characteristic of non-existence?
It refers to the fact that the aggregates, realms, and sense bases are always devoid of the nature of self and what belongs to self.
What is the characteristic of destruction?
It refers to the fact that conditioned phenomena, having arisen, immediately cease, temporarily existing and then becoming non-existent.
What is the characteristic of change?
It refers to the fact that conditioned phenomena arise differently, due to the transformation of dissimilar continuity.
What is the characteristic of separation?
It means that the power of the aggregates is lost, or that what belongs to others is grasped as one's own.
What is the characteristic of being present?
It means being in the present, impermanent, because the cause follows and one now experiences impermanence.
What is the characteristic of natural law?
It means future impermanence, because the cause follows and one will definitely experience it.
What is the characteristic of a moment?
It means that conditioned phenomena in a moment will definitely not remain.
What is the characteristic of continuity?
It means that since beginningless time, the arising and ceasing of conditioned phenomena have continued without interruption.
What are the characteristics of illness, etc.?
It means the changes in the four great elements, time, and life.
What is the characteristic of the various mental activities?

That is, sometimes a mind with craving arises, and sometimes a mind free from craving arises. In the same way, there is a mind with hatred and free from hatred, a mind with delusion and free from delusion, a contracted mind and a distracted mind, a depressed mind and an elated mind, a mind with restlessness and a mind free from restlessness, an uncalm mind and a calm mind, an undirected mind and a directed mind. Because of the arising and cessation of these various minds, the mind flows and turns.
What are the characteristics of the rise and fall of wealth?
That is, all that is good will eventually decline and change.
What are the characteristics of the formation and destruction of the world?
There are three kinds of formation and destruction by fire, water, and wind, which are the second, third, and fourth meditative absorptions.

Although the outer palaces and so forth of the fourth meditative absorption are not formed or destroyed by external calamities, the gods there are born and perish together with the palaces, and it is said that they have formation and destruction.
There are also three kinds of intermediate eons, namely those of famine, pestilence, and warfare.
These minor calamities only appear at the end of an eon.

That is to say, after the world has formed, the first intermediate eon is only decreasing, the last intermediate eon is only increasing, the eighteen intermediate eons are both increasing and decreasing, the twenty intermediate eons are the world properly being destroyed, the twenty intermediate eons are the world having been destroyed and remaining so, and the twenty intermediate eons are the world properly forming, and the twenty intermediate eons are the world having formed and remaining so.

These eighty intermediate eons combined are one great eon. By counting eons in this way, the lifespans of the gods of the form and formless realms are indicated. Because those sentient beings greedily savor samÄdhi, their meritorious power diminishes and is exhausted, and thus their lives end.

It means dying because both karma to be experienced in the present life and karma to be experienced in a later life are exhausted.
What are the characteristics of suffering?
That is, the three kinds of suffering, the eight kinds of suffering, and the six kinds of suffering, as explained above in detail. This is called the characteristic of suffering.
Why does the scripture say that if something is impermanent, then it is suffering?
Because the characteristic of suffering can be understood on the basis of impermanence in its two aspects.

That is, on the basis of impermanence in the aspect of origination, the nature of suffering as suffering can be understood.ğŸ”½On the basis of impermanence in the aspect of cessation, the nature of suffering as change can be understood.
On the basis of impermanence in the aspect of both origination and cessation, the nature of suffering as the conditioned can be understood.
In reliance on this meaning, the BhagavÄn said:
All conditioned forces are impermanent; all conditioned forces are subject to change.
Also in reliance on this meaning, he said: All feelings that I have described are suffering.

Also, in the conditioned forces that are associated with the two dharmas of origination and cessation, the nature of the eight kinds of suffering, such as origination, can be understood. Therefore, the Buddha said:
If something is impermanent, then it is suffering.
Moreover, regarding the suffering of arising, etc., that can be known in impermanent conditioned phenomena, the TathÄgata, relying on this hidden meaning, said:
Because of impermanence, there is suffering, but not all conditioned phenomena.
What are the characteristics of emptiness?
It means that where this is not existent, one correctly contemplates it as empty by this principle.
If where this is not existent, the remainder is existent, one correctly knows existence by this principle. This is called skillfully entering the nature of emptiness.
Correctly knowing means the meaning of non-erroneously.
Where and whose non-existence?
In the aggregates, realms, and sense bases, the non-existence of permanence, constancy, quiescence, and essential nature, as well as the self and what belongs to the self, etc.
By this principle, they are all empty.
Where and whose remainder?
It is precisely in this place that the nature of non-self exists.
The non-existence of self in self, and the existence of the nature of non-self, is called the nature of emptiness.
Therefore, the Blessed One spoke with hidden meaning, saying:
Existence is correctly known as existence, and non-existence is correctly known as non-existence.
There are also three kinds of emptiness, namely the emptiness of intrinsic nature, the emptiness of suchness, and the emptiness of the true nature.

The first is based on the observation of the nature of dependent arising, the second is based on the observation of the nature of dependent arising, and the third is based on the observation of the nature of perfect accomplishment.
What are the characteristics of non-self?

It means that the aggregates, realms, and sense bases are not characterized by the self as defined by those who propound the existence of a self. Because the aggregates, realms, and sense bases are devoid of the characteristics of a self, they are called the characteristics of non-self.
Therefore, the Blessed One spoke with a hidden meaning, saying:
All dharmas are without self.
As the World-Honored One said:
All of this is not mine, this is not my self, this is not my self.
One should contemplate this meaning with right wisdom as it truly is.
What is the meaning of these words?

It means that with regard to external matters, this is spoken with a hidden meaning that all of this is not mine. With regard to internal matters, this is spoken with a hidden meaning that this is not my self, this is not my self.
Why is this so?
Because with regard to external things, one only imagines them to be one's own, therefore only one's own is eliminated;
With regard to internal things, one imagines both self and what belongs to self, therefore both self and what belongs to self are eliminated.
The previous explanation of impermanence is all characterized by moments. How is this known?

Just as mind and mental factors are characterized by moments, one should know that form and so forth are also characterized by moments, because they are grasped by the mind, because they are equal to the mind in safety and danger, because they transform according to the mind, because they are the support of the mind, because they are born from the mind's dominant influence, and because they turn according to the mind's mastery.

Moreover, because they can be seen to change in the final stage, and because they naturally perish without waiting for conditions after arising, one should observe that form and so forth also cease moment by moment.
As the World-Honored One said:
All that exists in form, they are all either the four great elements or what is derived from the four great elements.
On what basis is this said?
Based on the meaning of possibility, it is said that they exist together in one place. The meaning of derivation is that they exist based on this.
If a certain type of primary element can be found in a certain aggregation, then know that this aggregation has only that primary element and not the others.
Some aggregations have only one primary element, some have two primary elements, and some have all four primary elements. The same is true of the derivative form.
If a certain type of derivative form can be found in a certain aggregation, then know that this aggregation has only that and not the others.
Some aggregations have only one type of derivative form, some have two types of derivative form, and some have many types of derivative form, as is appropriate in each case.

It is said that gross aggregations of form are composed of the aggregation of atoms. You should know that atoms have no substance. It is only by gradually analyzing and reducing the subtle parts through discernment that one reaches the limit of divisibility, and it is on the basis of this limit that atoms are established.
This is in order to eliminate the notion of a unitary whole, and also in order to realize that all form is not real.

Furthermore, the suffering of dharmas is generally of eight kinds, namely: vast and not tranquil suffering, tranquil suffering, tranquil and not tranquil suffering, middling and not tranquil suffering, slight and not tranquil suffering, slight and tranquil suffering, extremely slight and tranquil suffering, and abiding in the great tranquility that is not suffering but resembles suffering.
What is vast and not tranquil suffering?
It refers to those born in the desire realm who have not yet accumulated any wholesome roots.
What is tranquil suffering?
It refers to those who have already given rise to the wholesome roots conducive to liberation.
What is tranquil and not tranquil suffering?
It refers to those who, by means of the worldly path, have already become free from desire and have planted wholesome roots.
What is middling and not tranquil suffering?
It refers to those born in the form realm who are far removed from the wholesome roots conducive to liberation.
What is slight and not tranquil suffering?
It refers to those born in the formless realm who are far removed from the wholesome roots conducive to liberation.
What is slight and tranquil suffering?
It refers to those still in training.
What is extremely thin, peaceful, and suffering?
It refers to the six sense bases that are the condition for the life faculty of those who are no longer in training.
What is not suffering but appears as if it were suffering, abiding in great peace?
It refers to the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who have attained the ultimate, who are born in the various realms due to the power of their great compassionate vows.
Next, the suffering of death mentioned earlier.
There are three kinds of death: death with a wholesome mind, death with an unwholesome mind, and death with a neutral mind.

Death with a wholesome mind refers to when the mind is functioning clearly, either by the power of one's own wholesome roots or by being led by others, giving rise to a wholesome mind at the time of approaching death.

Death with an unwholesome mind refers to when the mind is also functioning clearly, either by the power of one's own unwholesome roots or by being led by others, giving rise to an unwholesome mind at the time of approaching death.

Those who die with a neutral mind are those who, whether in a state of clear and active mind or in a state of unclear and inactive mind, or due to the absence of two conditions, or due to the inability of practice, give rise to a neutral mind at the time of death.
For practitioners of purification, a cold sensation first arises in the lower part of the body at the time of death.
For practitioners of impurity, a cold sensation first arises in the upper part of the body at the time of death.
When the intermediate existence of a practitioner of impurity is born, its appearance manifests like the light of a black lamb or like a dark night.
When the intermediate existence of a practitioner of purification is born, its appearance manifests like the light of a white silk garment or like a clear night.
Moreover, this intermediate existence, in the state of being reborn in the desire realm or form realm, or after death in the formless realm, is also called a mind-born gandharva and so on.
It abides for a maximum of seven days, or it may die prematurely, or it may sometimes move.
Also, while in the intermediate state, one is able to accumulate karma, because good, etc., volition is drawn out and made to appear by the power of previous practice.
Also, one is able to see sentient beings of the same class.
Also, the form of the intermediate being resembles that of the place where it will be reborn.

Also, this intermediate being has no obstacles in the place to which it is going, just as one who possesses the supernormal powers of movement comes and goes quickly, but still has obstacles in the place of rebirth.

Also, this intermediate being in the place where it will be reborn is like a scale, rising and falling in accordance with the principle of cause and effect, and the time of its final sinking and rebirth is also like this.
While in the intermediate state, one gives rise to craving for the place where it will be reborn, and this craving also uses other passions as conditions to assist it.
This body of the intermediate being perishes together with craving, and the kalala body is born together with consciousness, and this is only retribution.
